entry.title: 在中国渗透我们未加密的电信网络后，美国官员敦促美国人使用加密应用程序发送短信和通话
entry.content:
凯文·科利尔 (Kevin Collier)，NBC 新闻报道：

在 AT&T 和 Verizon 等电信公司遭受前所未有的网络攻击之际，美国官员建议美国人使用加密消息应用程序，以确保他们的通信不被外国黑客发现。

这次黑客活动被微软称为“盐台风”，是美国历史上最大的情报泄露事件之一，而且尚未得到完全补救。官员们在周二的新闻电话会议上拒绝设定宣布该国电信系统没有入侵者的时间表。官员们告诉 NBC 新闻，中国对 AT&T、Verizon 和 Lumen Technologies 进行了黑客攻击，以监视客户。

中国驻华盛顿大使馆发言人没有立即回应置评请求。

不要屏住呼吸。

在周二的电话会议中，两名官员——一位不愿透露姓名的联邦调查局高级官员和网络安全和基础设施安全局网络安全执行助理主任杰夫·格林——都建议向那些希望最大限度地减少被攻击的可能性的美国人使用加密消息应用程序。中国拦截他们的通讯。

“我们的建议，我们在内部告诉人们的内容，在这里并不新鲜：加密是你的朋友，无论是在短信上还是如果你有能力使用加密的语音通信。即使对手能够拦截数据，如果数据被加密，也将变得不可能，”格林说。

对于联邦调查局来说，将加密称为“我们的朋友”似乎有点新鲜，但现在我想起来了，他们多年来的抱怨主要是关于获取锁定设备的访问权限，而不是窃听通信协议。他们对设备加密的倡导立场没有改变——他们仍然希望那里有一个“好人的后门”。我认为，他们的想法是，E2EE 通信是一件好事，因为它们可以防止外国对手的远程窃听——就像中国发起的这场活动一样。联邦调查局不需要拦截有线通信。当联邦调查局想要查看某人的通信时，他们会获得搜查令来扣押其设备。这就是为什么 FBI想要设备后门，但现在鼓励使用真正的 E2EE 协议。但这并不是说世界各地的执法机构不再幻想强制的“好人后门” 。

不过，以下是 NBC 新闻报道中的一段废话：

隐私倡导者长期以来一直主张使用端到端加密应用程序。 Signal 和 WhatsApp 自动在通话和消息中实施端到端加密。 Google Messages 和 iMessage 还可以对通话和短信进行端到端加密。

确实，通过 Signal 和 WhatsApp 进行的语音和文本通信始终受到端到端加密的保护。但 Google Messages 是一款 Android 应用程序，只能通过 SMS 和 RCS 处理短信，而不是语音。 Google Messages 中有一个“呼叫”按钮，但它只是使用“电话”应用程序拨打联系人 - 只是一个普通的老式未加密电话。 Google Messages 中的一些文本聊天是加密的，但仅限于那些使用 RCS 且所有参与者都使用最新版本的 Google Messages 的文本聊天。 Google Messages 确实提供了聊天加密状态的视觉指示器。 RCS标准没有加密； Google Messages 中的 E2EE RCS 聊天使用 Google 的专有扩展，并且是 Google Messages 应用程序独有的，因此 Google Messages 和其他应用程序（最明显的是 Apple Messages）之间的 RCS 聊天不会加密。

iMessage 不是一个应用程序。它是苹果公司的专有协议，可在其消息应用程序中使用。整个 iMessage 协议建立在端到端加密之上——所有 iMessage 消息从一开始就是 E2EE。 Apple 还提供用于语音和视频通话的 FaceTime，并且FaceTime 通话始终受到 E2EE 的保护。

★

entry.title: 2000 年安迪·格罗夫：《我学到了什么》
entry.content:
安迪·格罗夫 (Andy Grove) 在辞去英特尔首席执行官职务但仍担任董事长后接受 Esquire 采访时提出了一些宝贵的智慧：

利润是企业的命脉。不要让任何人告诉你不同的事情。

你必须明白自己的错误。研究他们的地狱。你不会再有机会犯同样的错误——你不可能在同一地点、同一时间再次踏入河流——但你还是有机会犯类似的错误。

地位是一件非常危险的事情。我遇到过很多人，他们以从不从提款机取钱为荣，他们太优秀了，以至于没有自己的电子邮件地址，因为那是给其他人的，但不是他们自己的。很难抗拒让自己与世界其他地方区分开来的诱惑。

格鲁夫在 1997 年英特尔的鼎盛时期仍然担任首席执行官，甚至没有办公室。 他在一个 8x9 英尺的小隔间里工作。

您今天看到的是一个非常非常快速的行业发展，与该行业同时成长的人们可以更好地理解该行业的环境。在此之前，我们中的许多人在商业领域度过的许多年的相关性都很有限。

这个行业与其他行业不同。计算机的功能不会逐渐变得更强大，而是会变得越来越强大。他们的力量呈指数级增长。

★
;

想象一下，如果你去看电影，他们的爆米花要价 8000 美元。

或者，想象一下您登上了飞机，他们告诉您安全带仅在头等舱可用。

当软件供应商向 IT 和安全专业人员征收可怕的 SSO 税时，您的愤怒不公正感可能类似于 IT 和安全专业人员的感受。

SSO 税是对单点登录收取高额费用的做法的名称，通常是将其纳入产品“企业层”的一部分。价格的上涨可能是惊人的——一个 CRM 的 SSO 层收费要高出 5000% 以上。按照这些价格，只有非常大的公司才有能力支付 SSO 费用。但问题是各种规模的公司都需要它。

在当今的世界中，凭证泄露是造成数据泄露的头号罪魁祸首，SSO 可以减少四处传播的弱密码、重复使用的密码的数量。这对于入职和离职也至关重要，因为 IT 人员只需管理单个开关，而不需要单独管理每个应用程序的访问。

公平地说，为 SSO 收取一些额外费用并没有什么问题——供应商构建或维护它不是免费的——但将其置于众多公司无法访问的范围之外是不负责任的行为，并且会让我们所有人都变得不那么安全。

尽管如此，在愤怒的客户迫使供应商取消税收之前，许多企业必须弄清楚如何在没有 SSO 的情况下生存。对于他们来说，最好的途径可能是密码管理器，它还可以减少弱凭据和重复使用的凭据，并实现跨团队的安全共享。无论如何，对于未与 SSO 集成的应用程序来说，密码管理器可能是一项不错的投资。

要了解有关 SSO 税的过去、现在和未来的更多信息，请阅读完整的博客文章。

entry.summary: 格罗夫的话不仅仅可以理解为建议，今天也可以理解为对英特尔过去 20 年所发生事情的事后剖析。
entry.content:
The Verge 的 Sean Hollister 对 Pat Gelsinger 如何被迫离开英特尔写了一篇精彩的高层总结：“英特尔发生了什么？ ”。不过，这里有一点点谨慎引起了我的注意：

基辛格接任最高职位之前情况到底有多糟糕？

不太好！经历了错误的赌注、多代芯片的延迟、质量保证问题，然后苹果决定放弃英特尔，转而采用其自主研发的基于 Arm 的芯片——结果证明这是好的，在笔记本电脑性能和电池寿命方面严重展示了英特尔的实力领域。我们在“ 英特尔落后的夏天”中写了所有相关内容。

英特尔早期也曾遭遇过失误：该公司长期以来一直后悔自己没有将英特尔芯片植入 iPhone 的决定，而且它也未能在 Android 手机芯片上执行。可以说，它错过了整个移动革命的机会。

对此没有任何争议。英特尔完全错过了移动领域。 iPhone从未使用过英特尔芯片，Apple Silicon芯片全部由台积电代工。苹果的芯片是业界最好的，这也是毫无争议的，唯一可以被视为合理竞争的移动芯片来自高通（也许还有三星）。英特尔从来都不是这场游戏的参与者，而英特尔不仅需要成为这场游戏的参与者，而且还需要占据主导地位。

这不仅是因为智能手机现在是一个比个人电脑行业更大的行业，而且英特尔也错过了成为手机制造商的主要供应商的机会。这很糟糕，但这还不是最糟糕的。正是这些基于 ARM 的移动芯片——Apple Silicon 和高通的 Snapdragon 系列——变得如此出色，以至于它们现在正在占领高端 PC 市场的大部分市场。部分源于ARM架构的固有优势，部分源于工程人才和战略，部分源于移动市场爆炸式增长带来的规模经济的深远效益。众所周知，苹果从 2020 年开始将整个 Mac 平台从英特尔芯片转移到 Apple Silicon。Mac“仅”占据全球 PC 市场的 15%，但 Mac 的整个市场份额处于高端水平。市场。失去 Mac 对英特尔来说是一个巨大的损失。现在， 高通和微软也出于同样的原因将 Windows 笔记本电脑推向 ARM 芯片：不仅仅是每瓦性能，而是纯粹的性能。 x86 CPU 仍然在游戏 PC 上占据主导地位，但即便如此， AMD 也被认为是其中的佼佼者。

在所有公司中，英特尔应该已经看到了这种情况发生的潜力。英特尔并没有认真对待“电话芯片”，但十年之内，那些表面上玩具的“电话芯片”就成为了世界上高端 PC 笔记本电脑上最好的 CPU，它们的效率优势也使它们在数据中心中也具有优势。苹果公司已经证明，它们对于工作站级台式机来说甚至更胜一筹。这正是英特尔在个人计算革命之初成为英特尔的方式。 20 世纪 70 年代和 80 年代初的“真正”计算机制造商将个人电脑视为纯粹的玩具。 IBM 措手不及，当他们看到有必要进入 PC 市场时，他们向英特尔寻求芯片，向微软寻求 DOS——英特尔和微软都利用了这一决策，最终在 PC 市场上形成了双打硬件/软件的主导地位。整个计算行业持续了整整四分之一个世纪。从英特尔的角度来看，x86 平台从一个“玩具”变成了从廉价笔记本电脑一直到数据中心级服务器的主导架构。

基于 ARM 的“电话芯片”对 x86 所做的事情与几十年前 x86“PC 芯片”对大型机所做的事情相同。同样，英伟达将“视频游戏爱好者的显卡”（也一度被认为仅仅是玩具）变成了现在（取决于股市波动）世界上最有价值的公司。他们与另一家希望英特尔获得芯片设计领导地位的公司：苹果公司并驾齐驱。作为一个企业，创造“世界上最好的芯片”仍然是一个令人难以置信、几乎难以想象的利润来源。苹果和英伟达都可以这样说，他们的芯片在不同的市场领域占据主导地位。如今，英特尔无法对其生产芯片的任何细分市场做出这样的评价。台积电为 Apple Silicon 生产所有芯片以及Nvidia 大部分领先芯片，在按市值排名的公司名单中排名第 9 位，前十名中的一席之地由英特尔占据。如今，英特尔排名第 180 位，并且有望跌出前 200 名。

英特尔绝不应该对这种威胁坐视不理。该公司长期担任首席执行官兼董事长（也是员工＃3）安迪·格罗夫（Andy Grove ）将他的自传命名为“只有偏执狂才能生存” 。他得出标题的完整段落：

商业的成功蕴含着其自身毁灭的种子。成功会滋生自满情绪。自满会导致失败。只有偏执狂才能生存。

格罗夫于 1998 年辞去首席执行官职务，并于 2005 年辞去董事长职务。在他之后，英特尔的任何人似乎都没有听过他说过的一句话。格罗夫的话不仅仅被解读为建议——今天，它们被解读为对英特尔过去 20 年急剧下滑的事后总结。

;
entry.title: ★ 安迪·格罗夫是对的
The Verge 推出订阅服务
entry.content:
尼莱·帕特尔：

很多人都喜欢 The Verge，以至于我们收到了数量惊人的留言，询问如何支付费用来支持我们的工作。众所周知，在过去几年中，随着开放网络的崩溃，许多优秀的网站和出版物都破产了，而且很明显，直接支持您喜爱的创作者是每个人在现代互联网上继续工作的重要组成部分。

与此同时，我们不想简单地对整个网站进行付费墙——传统新闻业正在退到付费墙后面，而废话却在平台上免费传播，这是一个悲剧。我们还认为我们的大而受欢迎的主页是值得投资的资源。因此，我们正在以免费增值模式重新思考 The Verge：我们的主页、核心新闻帖子、Decoder 采访记录、快速帖子、故事流和实时博客将保持免费。我们知道你们中的很多人每天都依赖我们来策划新闻，我们将继续专注于制作一个值得定期查看的精彩主页，无论您是否向我们付费。

我们的原创报告、评论和功能将在动态计量付费墙后面——你们中的许多人永远不会点击付费墙，但如果您经常阅读我们的文章，我们会要求您付费。

这听起来像是一个经过深思熟虑的平衡，既要保持网站的大部分内容向所有人开放，允许免费按流量访问有限数量的优质文章，又要从订阅者那里创造新的可持续收入流。太棒了。

算我为第一天订阅者吧。

entry.title: 谷歌搜索已经在下降
entry.content:
克里斯托弗·米姆斯 (Christopher Mims) 为《华尔街日报》撰稿（新闻+ ）：

公司的核心业务受到围攻。人们越来越多地从人工智能中得到答案。年轻一代正在使用其他平台来收集信息。随着网络上充斥着人工智能生成的内容，其搜索引擎提供的结果质量正在恶化。总而言之，这些力量可能会导致谷歌搜索流量的长期下降，以及由此产生的巨额利润，从而支撑其母公司 Alphabet 在 Waymo 自动驾驶部门等业务上的亏损押注。

谷歌面临的第一个危险是明确而现实的：当人们想要在互联网上搜索信息或购物时，他们就会转向谷歌的竞争对手，广告费用也随之而来。 eMarketer 预计，到 2025 年，谷歌在美国搜索广告市场的份额将自该公司开始跟踪以来首次跌破 50% 。

随附的图表（“美国搜索广告收入的估计份额”）表明，谷歌的下降是亚马逊的增长。基本上，谷歌可能仍然主导着通用网络搜索市场，但越来越多的人使用不是（或不仅仅是）通用网络搜索引擎的应用程序和服务进行搜索。原因是谷歌网络搜索变得越来越糟糕。

★

entry.title: 英特尔首席执行官帕特·基辛格退休；彭博社报道他被董事会驱逐
entry.content:
伊恩·金 (Ian King)、利亚娜·贝克 (Liana Baker) 和瑞安·古尔德 (Ryan Gould) 为彭博社报道： *

英特尔公司首席执行官帕特·基辛格(Pat Gelsinger)因董事会对他扭转这家标志性芯片制造商的计划失去信心而被迫辞职，这加剧了科技行业先驱之一的动荡。

据知情人士透露，上周基辛格与董事会会面，讨论该公司在赢回市场份额以及缩小与英伟达公司的差距方面取得的进展，冲突达到了白热化。这些不愿透露姓名的人士表示，他可以选择退休或被免职，并选择宣布结束在英特尔的职业生涯。

entry.title: 条纹和小条纹
entry.content:
我感谢 Crunchy Bagel（开发商 Quentin Zervaas 的公司）赞助本周的 DF RSS feed 来推广 Streaks，这是他们针对 iPhone 和 Apple Watch 的出色应用程序。 Streaks 是一个待办事项列表，可以帮助您养成良好的习惯。重点是激励你去做你想做的事情：从日常锻炼目标、学习一门新语言、服用维生素或戒掉坏习惯。任何事物。我从小就每天刷牙，但我从来不擅长用牙线——通常是在预定的洗牙前几天。我最近一直在使用 Streaks 养成每天使用牙线的习惯。 （我希望下次看牙医时能得到鼓励。）

Streaks 于 2016 年首次赞助 DF，当时我写的有关它的所有内容至今仍然适用。无论从视觉上还是概念上来说，这都是一个出色的设计。多年来我尝试过一些这样的应用程序——包括近年来的一些新应用程序——而杀死它们中的大多数的是摩擦。如果需要太多繁琐的步骤来标记你所做的事情，你就会停止使用该应用程序。条纹使得标记已完成的事情变得异常简单和快速。对于任何与活动相关的事情，您根本不必执行任何操作 - 它只是自动跟踪 HealthKit 中的信息（当然，需要您的许可）。在视觉设计方面，Streaks 既非常独特，又非常符合 iOS 风格——它看起来不像一个普通的 iOS 应用程序，但它看起来和感觉起来都非常像一个优秀的原生 iOS 应用程序。这种组合需要一双慧眼才能实现。 （不出所料，Streaks 几年前获得了 Apple 设计奖，并且经常在 App Store 中受到 Apple 推荐。）

iOS 在过去 8 年里并没有停滞不前，Zervaas 也没有。 Streaks 支持您希望在 iOS 应用程序中使用的所有最新功能，包括交互式小部件。 Streaks 的交互式小部件进一步减少了标记已完成事情的麻烦 - 交互式小部件实际上是为 Streaks 等应用程序制作的。 Streaks 还有一个很棒的 Apple Watch 配套应用程序。

我只接受对我很自豪支持的产品或服务的赞助。但 Streaks 太棒了，我想（再次）不遗余力地引起人们的注意。我并不是因为它是我的赞助商而用最高级的方式来赞扬它；而是因为它是我的赞助商。我这样做是因为它非常好。这是一次性购买，最新的更新添加了季节性主题，正好赶上圣诞节（以及您的新年决心）。

如果您对有助于强化日常习惯的应用程序有任何兴趣（或对出色的 UI 设计感兴趣），请查看 Streaks 。

如果您有小孩，请务必也尝试一下Little Streaks 。这是帮助孩子专注于日常生活的好方法：吃饭时间、睡觉时间、学习骑自行车、刷牙（和使用牙线！）——任何事情。 Little Streaks 的一次例程免费，或者使用代码“DARING”在订阅无限例程的第一年可享受 50% 的折扣。

entry.title: “建立法学硕士可能不会成为一项辉煌的事业”
entry.content:
卡尔·帕特森：

Chat-GPT 和 Claude.ai 等大型语言模型 (LLM) 非常出色且很酷。很多人认为他们将成为未来。也许它们是——但这并不意味着建造它们将是一项有利可图的业务。

在 20 世纪 60 年代，航空公司代表着未来。这就是为什么老电影中有那么多机场的华丽镜头。然而，事实证明航空公司不可避免地是一个垃圾行业。我乘坐过很多已经破产的航空公司：Monarch、WOW Air、Thomas Cook、Flybmi、Zoom。这些都是冠状病毒爆发之前的半身像——时代在变，但成为一家航空公司总是一个坏主意。

这很奇怪，因为其他企业，即使是看起来非常愚蠢的企业，利润要高得多。令人惊讶的是，销售碳酸饮料是一项了不起的生意。也许是最好的。可口可乐的股本回报率在任何一年都很少低于 30%。这似乎很不公平，因为成为一家航空公司是一项艰苦的工作，但生产可口可乐却相当容易。更令人恼火的是，可口可乐实际上并不自己生产可乐，而是外包给“装瓶公司”。他们实际上只是出售它。

这真是一篇精彩的文章。清晰、简洁、不复杂。我觉得很难争论。我曾多次提到去年从 Google 泄露的一篇内部论文，题为“我们没有护城河，OpenAI 也没有”。事实上，OpenAI 在全球范围内游说严格的人工智能监管，这表明他们也担心这一点——他们鼓励监管可以通过寻求监管护城河来解释，因为没有技术或商业模式护城河。

帕特森在阐述与航空业的比较时指出，商业航空公司只有两家供应商：波音和空客。他继续说道：

LLM 制造商有时会暗示他们的供应商是亚马逊网络服务、谷歌云等云公司。这还不错，因为你可以货比三家，让他们竞争来削减模型训练的巨额成本。

但实际上，LLM 制造商只有一个真正的供应商：NVIDIA。 NVIDIA 生产的芯片可供所有模型进行训练——无论云供应商是谁。这赋予了 NVIDIA 巨大的、近乎全面的定价能力。相对于 Anthropic 或 OpenAI，NVIDIA 的强大程度超出了空客或波音的想象。

目前，全球市值超过3万亿美元的公司有3家：苹果、英伟达和微软。市值超过 2 万亿美元的只有两家：亚马逊和谷歌。工程、培训和提供法学硕士学位并不是有护城河的业务。拥有护城河的业务是制造用于培训法学硕士的尖端计算机硬件，而这属于英伟达。

关于帕特森的文章我还有更多话要说，但我真的只想让你现在读一下它。

entry.title: Nathan Edwards 为 The Verge 评测 iMac M4
entry.content:
来自 Nathan Edwards 在 6/10 为 The Verge 发表的 M4 iMac 评论：

我也不喜欢支架没有高度调节功能，而且如果不购买完全不同的计算机，您就无法将其更换为更符合人体工程学的选项。 Apple 销售带有 VESA 安装座的 iMac 版本，但它根本不配备支架，而且大多数可调节高度的 VESA 安装座都不如 iMac 漂亮。 Studio Display 有一个高度可调节的支架选项，因此我们知道苹果可以制造出一款它愿意向世界推出的产品。只是这里还没有这样做。但无论如何。我有精装书。没关系。

为 The Verge 评测 Studio Display 的人不是 Edwards，而是 Nilay Patel，但在那次评测中，1,600 美元的成本（其中包括可选的可调节支架的 400 美元附加费）是“坏处”下的三个项目之一”。因此，不难猜测，如果 M4 iMac 有可选的可调节支架，它仍然会被列为缺点，因为苹果提供的这个选项肯定要花费至少 300 美元。

（自从它问世以来，我一直使用带有昂贵的纳米纹理和可调节高度选项的工作室显示器，并且认为这两种选项都非常值得。）

但爱德华兹的评论的奇怪之处在于，整个事情都是基于他没有看到一体机的吸引力。我个人也有同样的感觉。我的主电脑是 MacBook Pro，大部分时间我都会将其盖上盖子连接到前面提到的 Studio Display。如果我要购买专用台式 Mac，我会购买 Mac Mini 或 Mac Studio，并将其连接到 Studio Display。但 iMac 显然是为那些想要一体机的人设计的。

这是一个非常奇怪的、我敢说毫无意义的评论。这就像某人对自行车的评论，承认他们只步行或开车，却不明白为什么其他人不步行或开车去任何地方。理论上，不喜欢 X 类型的人可以写 X 类型的评论，而他们对该类型的厌恶可能会提供独特的视角。 （大卫·福斯特·华莱士（David Foster Wallace）在《我再也不会做的一件有趣的事情》中写了一篇该类型的杰作，标题是关于为期一周的加勒比海巡游。）但评论仍然需要相应地衡量产品的本质。有谁能制造出比 iMac 更好的一体机吗？如果有的话，是谁？如果不是，为什么是 6/10？

entry.title: John Siracusa 对 Delicious Library 1.0 的评论
entry.content:
20 年前的这个月，John Siracusa 以他独特的风格评论了 Delicious Library 1.0 的发布：

Mac 社区如此特别的部分原因在于，如此多的 Mac 开发人员都有与计算机无关的渴望，更重要的是，有相应的才能。我邀请您再次查看此应用程序中的一些屏幕截图和艺术作品。有人喜欢这些图形。有人为该应用程序窗口的每个像素而操心。有人知道成为艺术、音乐、书籍、电子游戏爱好者意味着什么。这是对编写优秀代码的能力的补充（而不是替代）。

所有这些人类设施和经验都被用来创建不仅仅是一个“程序”、“应用程序”或（上帝禁止）“可执行文件”，而是一封写给收藏家的数字情书。 Delicious Monster，从它的产品到它的网站，都散发着激情和乐趣的精神。 “我的工作从未如此快乐”，威尔·希普利在一封电子邮件中告诉我。 “我认为这体现在成品中。”

我也这么认为。虽然只是1.0版本，但是很好吃。

重读这篇评论——我在发表时第一次链接到它，几乎没有评论——让我想起了几件事。首先，锡拉库扎是我在这个圈子里感觉到有竞争力的少数作家之一。整件事真是太好了，触及了许多难以用语言表达的微妙之处。 （在某些方面，最好通过互联网档案馆以原始的多页布局阅读，但这些存档版本莫名其妙地缺少一些（但不是全部）屏幕截图，并且对于像 Delicious Library 这样视觉上雄心勃勃的应用程序进行审查，屏幕截图是必不可少的，但是当前的 Ars Technica 版本的评论虽然具有所有内联图像，但缺少Delicious Library 主窗口的“更大版本”打开我在 a 中托管的版本。另请注意，“较大版本”在 20 年前的含义有所不同 - 它只有 183 KB，但却是评论中最大的图像。）

其次，我忘记了 Delicious Library 1.0 刚推出时有多么雄心勃勃。我记得 Delicious Library 最终支持通过网络摄像头进行条形码扫描，但该功能实际上在 1.0 版本中就已经存在。它的效果非常好。而且该功能远远领先于当时的时代。 2004 年， Mac 还没有配备内置摄像头。相反，我们都购买了苹果公司价值 150 美元的独立 iSight 摄像头，它通过 FireWire 连接。 （多么华丽的设备啊。）在他热情洋溢的评论结束时，Siracusa（毫不奇怪）有一个附加功能的愿望清单，但 Delicious Library 1.0 中的内容远远超出了“最小可行产品”。它体现了苹果公司和史蒂夫·乔布斯自己的精神：一经推出就轰动一时。它让你惊叹“哇！”然后你会想，“哦，但如果它......那就太酷了”，事实证明，它也做到了。

确实好吃。

★

entry.title: 美味图书馆的终结
entry.content:
威尔·希普利 (Wil Shipley) 论乳齿象：

亚马逊已经关闭了允许 Delicious Library 查找项目的源，不幸的是，该应用程序仅限于用户已有的（或手动输入的）内容。

没有就此事联系我。

我已将其从 Mac App Store 中撤下并关闭了该网站，这样就不会有人意外购买无法正常运行的应用程序。

一个时代的结束，但令人惊讶的是它至今仍然有效。 （希普利已经在苹果公司担任全职工程师三年了。）

很难形容《美味图书馆》 问世时的轰动程度和影响力。 Delicious Library 同时非常有用，以非常实用的方式，并且痴迷于其丰富的用户界面，但除了看起来很酷之外没有其他任何目的。这款应用程序不仅因其外观而受到赞扬，而且还达到了引起许多用户共鸣的目的。大约十年来，似乎大多数流行的新应用程序都会像 Delicious Library 那样设计。然后苹果在 2013 年放弃了 iOS 7，而现在，再没有像这样的应用程序了。无论我们作为一个行业在长达十年的 iOS 7 风格扁平化设计趋势中迷失了什么，Delicious Library 都体现了这一点。

他们在推广应用程序的方式上甚至非常聪明和创新。 Delicious Monster第一次赞助 Daring Fireball 一周，他们的赞助信息全文如下：

整理你喜欢的东西。
摆脱你不喜欢的东西。
美味图书馆2.

当他们创建 iPhone 版本的 Delicious Library 时，他们通过这个令人愉悦的复杂但绝对低保真的定格动画视频宣布了这一消息。

20 年过去了，回顾任何艺术形式都不可避免地会产生一些怀旧之情。但天哪，Delicious Library 是独立应用程序开发时代的典范，遗憾的是，这个时代基本上已经结束了。毫不掩饰这一点：《美味图书馆》是一件创造性的艺术作品。

★

entry.title: OpenAI 可能会开发一个网络浏览器
entry.content:
Erin Woo、Sahil Patel 和 Amir Efrati，《The Information》的报道（可惜是付费墙）：

OpenAI 正准备向谷歌发起正面进攻。据看过 ChatGPT 原型或设计的人士透露，ChatGPT 所有者最近考虑开发一款与其聊天机器人结合的网络浏览器，并且已经单独讨论或达成了协议，为旅游、食品、房地产和零售网站提供搜索功能。产品。 [...]

制作网络浏览器可以帮助 OpenAI 更好地控制人们使用网络的主要网关，并进一步推动 ChatGPT 的发展，ChatGPT 在推出仅两年后每周就有超过 3 亿的用户。目前尚不清楚 ChatGPT 浏览器的功能与其他浏览器的功能有何不同。

为了表达对浏览器的兴趣，几个月前 OpenAI 聘请了 Google Chrome 团队的创始成员 Ben Goodger。最近聘请的另一位员工是 Darin Fisher，他与 Goodger 一起开发了 Chrome。

但多位人士表示，OpenAI 距离推出浏览器还差得很远。

古德格和费舍尔的招聘并不是秘密——两人都在 LinkedIn 上保持最新的个人资料——仅仅因为两个人之前创建过新的网络浏览器（甚至多次），他们的新工作就正在创建一个新的网络浏览器。但这确实感觉是一个不错的猜测。

Fisher 最近在The Browser Company工作了两年，负责开发Arc ，这是一款创新浏览器，我很欣赏它的原创性，但它根本不适合我。浏览器公司也在不断变化，正在开发 Arc 2.0和尚未命名的第二个项目，该项目可能是更传统的 Web 浏览器。

entry.title: [赞助商] 条纹和小条纹
Apple TV 的硬件状况良好
entry.content:
马克·古尔曼 (Mark Gurman) 在他的每周 Power On 专栏中：

对于苹果来说，在电视硬件方面最好的方案是一根便宜的棒（也许没有物理遥控器——用你的 iPhone 代替）。这是苹果营销高管所厌恶的想法，但它将帮助该公司迅速扩大其影响力。如果消费者想要更多的电量和存储空间，他们可以选择当前的盒子。

最重要的是，苹果可以提供类似新款 Mac mini 的产品，提供最佳的流媒体质量和游戏选项。在本练习中，我们将这三个层称为 Apple TV SE、Apple TV 和 Apple TV Max。它将采用与 iPhone、Mac、iPad、AirPods、Apple Watch 甚至 Apple Pencil 相同的“好、更好、最好”策略。

这些建议都没有任何意义。关于这两种想法的唯一有趣的事情是试图确定哪一个更糟糕。

流媒体棒是垃圾，而苹果不生产垃圾。我还认为流媒体棒正在迅速走上渡渡鸟的道路——当电视机没有内置集成主要流媒体平台的“智能”体验时，它们是一种权宜之计的低成本解决方案。这些内置集成消除了对流媒体棒的需求， Apple TV 现在已内置于所有主要品牌的电视中，包括三星、索尼、LG 和 Vizio。这是 Apple TV应用程序，不是完整的 Apple TV tvOS 平台，但可以满足 Apple 的需求。我认为不可能通过从 HDMI 端口获取电源的棒状计算机来提供全保真 tvOS 体验，并且通过省略该死的遥控器当然不可能做到这一点。今天，争论苹果需要甚至应该制造一款廉价电视棒就像 2009 年那些愚蠢的专栏争论苹果需要制造一款上网本来与 300 美元的劣质笔记本电脑竞争一样。 Apple TV 之于机顶盒就像 Mac 之于 PC 一样——它永远不会在整个市场中占据很大份额，但它在高端市场占据主导地位，迎合真正关心的人。

至于 Gurman 的高端硬件理念，Mac Mini 的起价为 600 美元。将此类硬件连接到电视有什么意义？ Mac Mini不会比现有的Apple TV 4K报价提供更好的流质量。 4K是4K，即使是较旧的Apple TV硬件也可以完美地流。而且，从理论上讲，与当前Apple TV 4K硬件中的iPhone-13-13时代A15仿生芯片相比，Mac-Mini-Caliber Apple TV可以提供更好的游戏，如今有零TVOS游戏，以此为目标，并且针对这样的硬件，并且游戏开发人员几乎没有理由将这种“ Apple TV Pro”设备瞄准，因为几乎没有人会购买。无论游戏的原因如何，今天在TVO上没有大事，缺少“ Pro” 500美元或600美元的硬件层并不是其中之一。

我认为苹果的入口价格应该将其降至99美元（目前为129美元），即使只是为了支持Apple Intelligence，他们迟早需要更新硬件。 （也许是明年秋天的A18或A18 Pro - 当前的A15 Apple TV 4K车型在芯片在iPhone 13中首次亮相后一年就发布了。）但是，Apple TV的硬件故事很好。

★

entry.summary: 通过查看Apple的应用程序的历史，思考像素策略的未来。
entry.content:
我本周关于Shazam历史的帖子使我想到了Apple的唱片记录。 苹果公司于2018年收购了Shazam ，并很快将其功能融入了Siri。但是他们还保持了Shazam应用程序的运行，包括Android版本。他们甚至仍然有一个独立的Shazam网站。我会说这是一个使每个人都开心的收购：现有用户仍然拥有一个很棒的Shazam应用程序，而核心“这是什么歌？”功能已变得更加可用和可访问。

目前，在库比蒂诺（和立陶宛）以外，在宣布苹果待定的收购之后，我们对像素机和摄影机的未来持有不确定性。在广泛的笔触中，让我们考虑一下苹果公司可能获得现有流行应用程序的战略原因，或者在这种情况下为应用程序。

  • 使该应用程序依靠Apple的所有权- 示例包括Logic ，Apple通过购买母公司Emagic在2002年获得的逻辑，并进一步回到Filemaker 。

  • 关闭应用程序并将基础技术烘烤到操作系统中- 例如：Siri和Dark Sky。 Siri于2010年2月作为独立iPhone应用首次亮相。苹果在两个月后购买了母公司，Siri在秋季使用iPhone 4S内置在iOS中的“ beta”软件，这时苹果从应用程序中拉出了独立的Siri应用程序店铺。我不记得Siri是一个独立的应用程序，曾经很受欢迎。无论您在随后的几年中如何看待Siri的质量和实用性，与独立应用程序相比，这是系统级功能更有意义的事情。很多人对Siri有很多愿望，但是我从未见过有人说“我希望Siri仍然只是一个独立的应用程序。”

    黑暗的天空更加复杂。获得它后，苹果将黑暗的天空作为一个独立的（和跨平台）应用程序，但仅在过渡时期。此次收购的目的是将Dark Sky的一些预测技术集成到Apple自己的天气应用程序和第三方应用程序可用的WeatherKit System框架中。 顽固的黑暗天空迷错过了它，有些发誓Weatherkit关于即将降水的警告并不像黑暗的天空那样准确，但很难说苹果公司对Dark Sky使用者的使用者很肮脏。

  • 收购了开发人员和设计师，但要废除该应用程序- 这是在行业中发生的，但不与Apple进行。我可以想到许多有才华的独立开发人员和设计师关闭商店并为苹果公司工作的例子，但是我想不出任何一个很好的流行应用程序的好例子。我能想到的最悲惨的收购是当Facebook（现在的Meta）收购Pusp Pop Press时，这是一支具有才华横溢的团队，为现代制作了出版工具，这可能是我一生中见过的最令人印象深刻的软件。而且，POOF，当Push Pop团队加入Facebook时，整个事情才被关闭。在Facebook中，同一支团队创建了Facebook论文，该论文拥护了许多使Push Pop的交互式发布工具引人注目的原则，但是Facebook Paper（a，对于这个世界来说都不是很长的。 Facebook论文是如此的好，是如此的前瞻性，如此创新，以至于我第一次创建一个Facebook帐户。

  • 仅仅是为了关闭反竞争性的恶心，就可以从反竞争力的情况下购买该应用程序- 软件行业充满了收购，其唯一目的是取消竞争， 1 ，但我不记得一个苹果这样做的一个例子。就像素示操作和摄影仪而言，这没有任何意义 - 都没有与Apple所做的任何事物竞争，并且它们仅作为Apple Platform上的应用程序可用。

最重要的是，作为用户，我们希望在一家大公司获得一个心爱的应用程序之后，是该应用程序的用户保持快乐的结果。这可能意味着要保持应用程序的运行，例如使用逻辑。或者这可能意味着要删除独立应用程序，但将应用程序的核心功能带入操作系统本身，就像黑暗的天空一样。有时候，这是一种混合，就像与Shazam一样。这样的另一个示例是工作流程，它开始了iOS的第三方自动化实用程序的生活，但苹果公司于2017年收购并变成了捷径。任何喜欢Workflow的人肯定都喜欢捷径 - 它的功能强大和能力作为Apple的OS级技术要比以往任何时候都希望成为第三方应用程序。

其他例子：

  • Beats在2014年以30亿美元的价格收购，仍然是Apple历史上最大的收购。 2节音乐成为Apple Music的基础。

  • 说到音乐，iTunes始于Mac的第三方MP3播放器Soundjam MP的生活。 iTunes不仅仅是重塑品牌，这是对Soundjam的完整重新设计和重新思考，但基本上实现了与Soundjam相同的目的。 （Apple考虑的另一个选择是购买Panic ，其声音是Soundjam的Arch Rival。）

  • 最终削减是一次收购 - 苹果于1998年从Macromedia购买了它。但这很奇怪，因为苹果公司购买了它并在运输之前雇用了该团队。此次收购不仅是我们今天知道的最终削减专业人士的基础，而且对iMovie也是如此。

  • TestFlight是一次收购，就像Siri和Workflow/Jurpcuts一样，是一种概念，它需要成为实现其目标的第一方产品。

  • Shake是一种专业的视频合成工具，是一个罕见的悲伤长号。苹果公司在2002年收购了母公司，但在2009年停止了Shake。某些功能在Final Cut Pro中使用，但对于喜欢Shake的任何人来说，这似乎并不是成功的收购。 3

  • 2021年， 苹果公司购买了PrimePhonic ，并于2023年将其变成了Apple Music Classical 。对于PrimePhonic粉丝来说，似乎是一个完全的胜利。

  • 苹果公司进行了许多小型收购，这些收购都被汇入了改进苹果地图。例如， Engark ，它是用于公交信息的独立应用程序，似乎是Apple Maps现在具有良好运输功能的基础。

一家大型公司购买一家制作非常酷的应用程序，然后以某种方式破坏该应用程序的小型公司很普遍。有时，通过将其转换为无法识别的，但通常会通过不感兴趣或忽视。苹果公司是一家非常大的公司，PixelMator是一家拥有两个非常酷的应用程序的小公司。但是，对苹果的收购历史的检查并没有给我任何警报。苹果确实确实通过酷应用获取来做到正确。

苹果尊重制作出色应用的艺术。尤其是像素计算机实在太好了，无法报废，而且Apple自从MacPaint以来就没有制作自己的位图映像编辑应用程序。像PixelMator这样的事情确实会在Final Cut Pro和Logic Pro作为Apple“ Pro Tool”的旁边插入。我不知道他们是否会保留名称，但是我认为该应用程序将在Apple Branding以Photoshop竞争对手的身份发布，用于Mac和iPad。 （iOS的PixelMator当前在iPad和iPhone上都运行，但是Apple自己的Pro Tools（最终剪切和逻辑）仅是iPad。）

我不确定苹果是否有能力保持光弹器的兴趣，直接与Lightroom竞争 - 苹果在10年前停止孔径时只是避开了一个市场。但是也许他们现在后悔离开了孔。我只是不确定光镜与成为Lightroom的可靠替代品有多近。

另一个路径是退休应用程序，并将最佳功能和技术（例如其ML超级分辨率升级）折叠为照片和/或进入所有Apple平台上所有应用程序可用的系统级核心图像框架。我可以看到最好的光：如何进入照片。对于像素机来说，这不是事实。除非Apple想让像素示例成为Apple品牌的Pro工具，否则对我的收购对我来说是没有意义的。明年我们会找出答案。

  1. 当他们 在2005年获得Macromedia时，我仍然无法完全原谅Adobe的徒手做。 Macromedia是Adobe在创意设计工具中的Arch竞争对手，Freehand是插图画家在矢量图形市场中的竞争对手。徒手对我来说很有意义，以插画家从未做过的方式。太好了。 ↩︎

  2. 当然，根据苹果历史上的重要性，最大的收购是他们的4亿美元交易，以使该公司在1996年底与下一个公司团聚。这是毫无争议的。这可以说是整个计算历史上最有影响力的收购。但是，我也认为， 在2008年以2.78亿美元的价格收购PA Semi几乎毫无争议，这远比拍卖的收购要重要得多。这为苹果硅铺平了道路，苹果硅是一项倡议，其对苹果在此后几年的重要性很难夸大其词。 ↩︎︎

  3. 引用Wikipedia的引用：“版本2于1999年初发布Windows NT和Irix，每批许可证的价格为9,900美元，或仅渲染许可证的$ 3,900，这是如何开眼界的有关专业软件市场如何变化的大开眼界的情况。在接下来的几年中，Shake迅速成为故事片视觉效果行业中的标准合成软件。在2002年，Apple Computer什么也没真正获得。几个月后，发布了2.5版，引入了Mac OS X兼容性。为了加强Mac在生产工作室中的地位，Mac版本的价格为4,950美元（相当于2023年的8,385美元），并为非MAC操作系统的用户提供了不迁移的额外费用加倍许可证数量的价格到Mac OS X。”每个座位$ 5,000，折扣50％！ ↩︎︎

entry.title: “ X与特朗普政府之间的模糊界限”
entry.content:
迈克·马斯尼克（Mike Masnick），为MSNBC写作：

事实证明，当您的团队在进行爬行时，“ Twitter Files”工作人员“爬行的威权主义”并不是那么令人毛骨悚然。

以前，我们被告知白宫官员只是向社交媒体公司伸出关于选举错误的信息是一种民主终结的威胁。现在，世界上最富有的人已经公开利用他的平台来促进一位候选人，骑了这个竞选活动的成功，并……板球。沉默震耳欲聋。

甚至没有建议马斯克必须退出他对X的所有权。没有人期望这一点。没有讨论Musk如何在自己的“政府效率部”的平台上建立整个帐户，并给它一个“灰色”的复选标记 - 将其表示为经过验证的政府实体。

关于私人和公共利益的合并，“ Twitter文件”作家和助推器的沉默或欢呼 - 他们认为这是对西方文明的威胁，甚至没有发生，这是对信誉的信誉。他们只是一个方便的政治库德格尔，一旦一个实际的政府社会媒体联盟受益，就很快就被放弃了。

一个名叫弗兰克·威尔霍特（Frank Wilhoit）的人在2018年创造了一句经常引用的格言，我发现了深刻的言论，尤其是在美国政治中特朗普时代的荒谬伪善时：“保守主义正是一个命题，包括一个命题，才能：法律保护但不束缚的组织与法律约束但不保护的群体。”

但这不仅仅是法律，尽管法律是股份最高的地方。这是一切，包括惯例和规范。

无论您认为Biden Administration所做的一切如何推动Twitter（以及其他社交媒体平台，但让我们坚持使用Twitter/X）来削减政府认为“错误信息”的看法，与Musk拥有所有权的所有权相比，它显得显而易见平台并将其转变为这次选举的明确的亲特朗普平台。我并不是说那是非法的，或者应该是非法的。我是说关于“ Twitter档案”的整个论点是，Twitter的前任领导将他们的拇指放在了规模上，以遵守拜登政府的意愿。我和马斯尼克在一起 - 我认为这甚至不是真的。但是，即使您购买了“ Twitter文件”论文，它也大约是量表的一侧的拇指。然后马斯克购买了Twitter，将其改名为X，然后在秤的另一侧放下了砧。 “ Twitter文件”的论点并不是说量表的错误方面受到偏见的优势，而是平台所有者应该仔细避免任何模糊的偏见暗示。但是现在在这里，我们与埃隆·马斯克（Elon Musk）在一起，是特朗普2.0政府的事实上的成员，甚至没有一个批评家看到一个问题。

伪善被烤在他们的世界观中。因此，我们对抗它，这不能仅仅是指出他们的伪善，因为他们看不到它，也不在乎。我对马斯尼克（Masnick）的作品最大的疑问是头条新闻（也许他没有写）：X与即将到来的特朗普政府之间的界线并没有模糊 - 已被删除。

entry.summary: 我对任何希望基于新闻通讯模型创建新站点的作家的建议都是考虑替换 *last *，而不是第一。
entry.content:
Anil Dash，“不要称其为替代”：

当我们从属于法西斯大亨拥有的名称时，我们会限制我们的想象力。想象一本书的作者告诉人们“阅读我的亚马逊”。一位出色的导演，试图通过说“点击我的Max”来宣传他们的电影。这就是他们在围墙花园的背景下提到自己的作品和自己的声音时，他们腌制了大脑。没有“我的替代”之类的东西，只有您的写作，也没有与纯粹的纯粹化世界的斗争。

我对上述情况感到不满，但只有我嫉妒我从未想过要与作者说“阅读我的亚马逊”的比喻。关于替代的出版物不比WordPress上的博客更“替代”是“ WordPress”。这确实是一个很漂亮的，但狡猾的技巧，替代使这一句话成为一件事情。

据提醒，替代是一个由极端分子制定的政治项目，其目标是通过采用良好的创作者的工作来使激进，仇恨的议程正常化，以服务对弱势群体的交叉促进攻击。您不必相信我的话；替补的首席执行官明确表示，他们不会禁止明确吐出仇恨的人，当面对猖ramp的白人至上主义的宣传时，他们从现场获利时，他们就撤下了……四个纳粹。四。现在还有更多的东西，他们想使用您的电子邮件通讯来交叉宣传，并将其合法化。如果您的好小通讯也在那里，没有人可以禁止可恶的内容网站，而您的订户沉思都是所需的封面。

我认识很多人，我敬佩他们的意见，他们在这里的意见与Dash一样。我会不同意。我认为替代将自己视为出版工具和平台。他们不是在这里促进任何特定方面。对于他们来说，拒绝出版某人过于右翼的人比WordPress或Medium或Github或YouTube拒绝出版某人更有意义。我认为，替代是这样的。

您可能会不同意。就像我说的那样，我知道一群像Dash一样看到替代品的好人，并且拒绝在替补平台上付费审查员的立场。我个人可以说的是，我在替代上阅读并付款，并且在过去的几周中，我尝试使用了他们的iOS应用程序（稍后再仔细详细介绍），而且我从未见过甚至右翼模糊的事物，更不用说可恶了。不是闻。如果在那里，我永远不会看到它。如果我从未看到过，我就不在乎。 1

我反对的不是他们允许谁在平台上发布的人，而是他们如何介绍所有出版物。人们确实将替代的出版物称为“替代”。而且替代出版物看起来都一样，其中大多数都直到那个细长的衬线字体，频谱， 2被kern散布得如此宽松，看起来像是牙齿需要正极的牙齿。本身本身并不是丑陋的字体，但它非常独特，我认为这对替代出版物作为离散独立实体的替代出版物之间的品牌线的模糊性有所贡献，或者仅仅是“替代”作为雨伞出版物的部分。

非常故意的是，一开始就试图通过这两种方式来实现这一目标。他们说，平台上的出版物是独立的声音和品牌。但是他们将它们全部作为替代的一部分。它们看起来都一样，看起来都像“替代”。我真的不明白为什么任何作家试图独立建立自己的作家都会以这种方式耕种自己的品牌。这是独立的幻想。

我绝对鄙视替代出版物的主页，通常只不过是您的电子邮件地址的注册字段，可以通过电子邮件获取出版物，而一个小的“不感谢”链接可以实际阅读该死的东西。当我看到该页面的时间一半，我只是将标签从恶意中关闭。在什么世界中，“不，谢谢”一个很好的链接，可以传达“让我阅读我来这里阅读的东西”的意思？

替换的应用程序以及公司的主页默认将自己显示为像Twitter一样的短形式发布平台。好像我们现在需要的是另一个类似Twitter的平台。但是尤其是：为什么有人想参加与一个特定出版平台相关的社交平台？作为读者，这对我没有任何意义，我也不会看到平台上对作家的吸引力。从替代自己的角度来看，这只有战略性。如果作为作家，您与听众的反馈和社交互动与替代自己的社交图相关，那么您的出版物也与替代相关。它是如此透明的锁定游戏，以至于几乎很难反对它。就在锡罐上。但是，不使用它并不难。

替代甚至不再拥有我订阅的大多数新闻通讯式作家。凯西·牛顿（Casey Newton）在一月份将平台游戏从替代者转移到幽灵。克雷格·卡卡特拉（Craig Calcaterra）将他出色的注重棒球的咖啡和流行文化的咖啡杯从替代品到贝希伊夫（Beehiiv）移动了。 3莫莉·怀特（Molly White）在幽灵上需要引用。我最新的付费订阅是美国有线电视新闻网（CNN）外籍奥利弗·达西（Oliver Darcy）的新媒体独立地位，他选择了贝希夫（Beehiiv）。当然还有我的朋友和抖动的联合主持人本·汤普森（Ben Thompson），他的Stratechery在他自己的平台护照上奔跑，不仅长期替代了替代，而且还可以作为他们复制的模型。 （替代的俯仰甲板是“盒子里的Stratechery”。）所有这些网站都以自己的品牌看起来很独特。所有这些都提供了比替代更好的订阅和交付管理接口。

我对任何希望根据新闻通讯模型创建新网站的作家的建议是最后一次考虑替换，而不是先考虑替代。不是因为替代是纳粹酒吧，我认为这根本不是纳粹酒吧，而是因为显然有更好的选择，而公司的长期目标显然是平台锁定。

  1. 我对社交媒体平台也有同样的感觉。在Mastodon，Bluesky，Instagram和Threads上，我是否会发现人们令人反感？确实。在YouTube上？更肯定的是。我在乎吗？不，因为我倾向于看不到他们的帖子，当一个人弹出时，我可以阻止或静音，而且我再也见不到它们了。这与X（前Twitter）相反，在前Twitter上，许多帖子的最高答复来自一流的狗屎巨魔。越来越多的我发现X一个令人不愉快的地方来投入我的任何注意力，所以我越来越少了。我不在我不喜欢食物的餐厅吃饭，X的食物味道不好，而且越来越糟。 ↩︎︎

entry.title: ★关于 - 反对 - 替换
苹果首次直接出售苹果新闻广告
entry.content:
萨拉·菲舍尔（Sara Fischer），《 Axios报道：

苹果已经开始为苹果新闻出售自己的广告库存，两个熟悉这项工作的消息来源告诉Axios。它正在推销新的广告单元，希望能为自己及其出版伙伴最大化收入。 [...]

  • 出版商将在其文章中获得苹果出售的广告收入的70％。
  • They will get a percentage of the ad revenue sold by Apple within the Apple News feed, dependent on engagement with their content.
  • Apple News publishers will continue to receive 100% of the revenue from the advertising that they sell against their content in the app.

Apple News+ is a really good product. Scanning its main Today tab in the morning has become my modern-day equivalent of scanning the front page of a printed newspaper — a way to get a sense of what's going on in world news. There's a level of editorial curation and presentation in Apple News that I don't think has a peer. Apple News itself doesn't publish or report anything, but there's clearly a talented, level-headed editorial team that is picking and choosing the most important and most interesting (which are often very different things) stories from a wide variety of sources. So maybe a better analogy to the bygone era of print isn't scanning the front page of a newspaper, but rather stopping at a good big-city newsstand where you could scan the front pages of a slew of newspapers from around the country (and世界）。

I don't look to Apple News for anything related to tech. I definitely want to do that via RSS (which for me means NetNewsWire ), the web (Safari), and social media. But for national, world, and general interest news, Apple News is really good. I don't know what it's like without a News+ subscription, but with one, it's truly excellent. And a News+ subscription gets you access to a bunch of great publications with paywalls on the web.

If you cemented your opinion of Apple News years ago and tuned out, you should give it a fresh look — especially if you have a “free” News+ subscription via Apple One.

But, my god, the ads suck — low-rent and highly repetitive. I posted screen recordings over the summer illustrating this. It seems like recently, though, I've seen fewer ads, and they've gotten less repetitive. I just spent a few minutes now perusing the Today tab while writing this post, and I read a bunch of articles without seeing any ads at all. For me at least, the Apple News ad experience seems to be getting better already. But there's still so much room for improvement.

Whenever I write about this, some readers will comment that, to their minds, a paid subscription like Apple News+ should bestow a completely ad-free experience. That's how streaming video and music subscriptions tend to work, but even there — as I just posted regarding Disney+ — many people are choosing lower-priced streaming subscriptions subsidized by ads. The economics for ad-free news just don't work, and never have. News+ isn't like TV+, where Apple owns or has paid for the rights to all of the content.

entry.summary: I met Dr. Oz ten years ago.
entry.content:
The Hollywood Reporter, which of course is where one now goes to find news of incoming Executive Branch appointments and nominations, “ Trump Nominates Dr. Mehmet Oz to Run Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services ”:

“America is facing a Healthcare Crisis, and there may be no Physician more qualified and capable than Dr. Oz to Make America Healthy Again,” Trump said in a statement. “He is an eminent Physician, Heart Surgeon, Inventor, and World-Class Communicator, who has been at the forefront of healthy living for decades. Dr. Oz will work closely with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to take on the illness industrial complex, and all the horrible chronic diseases left in its wake.”

He added, “He won nine Daytime Emmy Awards hosting The Dr. Oz Show, where he taught millions of Americans how to make healthier lifestyle choices, and gave a strong voice to the key pillars of the MAHA Movement.”

I met Dr. Oz ten years ago. It was after the Apple event on Tuesday, 9 September 2014, at the Flint Center in Cupertino, where Apple unveiled Apple Watch after introducing the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus. Apple had erected a startlingly large temporary building in front of the Flint Center, which, post-event, was opened to attending media and celebrities to showcase Apple Watch's various capabilities. But post-event press briefings were held inside the Flint Center, in a byzantine complex of subterranean rooms beneath the massive ground floor auditorium.

I had a one-on-one off-the-record briefing with Jony Ive. (Fascinating and fun — we spent most of the all-too-brief 30 minutes talking about watch bands and the exquisite packaging and charging case of the Edition models.) The waiting area for these press briefings was set up to look a bit like a mostly empty Apple Store. The central focus of this waiting area was a large table with a glass top; under the glass were a variety of Apple Watch models. The table was a prototype of the ones that Apple would put in its retail stores , for which they obtained multiple patents. While I was waiting for my briefing with Ive, the only other person from the media waiting with me was Oz.

It's a weird thing to be alone, effectively, with someone of Oz's celebrity. It's like being in a room with a million dollars in $100 bills stacked in a perfectly-arranged pyramid. No matter how hard you try to direct your attention, your mind keeps popping back to Holy shit, there's a million dollars in cash right there . His hair was perfect, his shirt crisply pressed. It was a very nice shirt. He smiled at all times, and seemed genuinely happy to be there, and genuinely interested in Apple Watch, but not for what Apple Watch actually was or could be, but simply because it was a major new thing, and he was a VIP invitee at the introduction of this major new thing. And my mind would pop, for the umpteenth time, Holy shit, that's Dr. Oz right there.

We spent an unceasingly awkward 10 minutes circling around that table together. He never shut up. He chattered, nonstop, with inane observations, like “Hey, look at that one, it's orange! What's that one, leather?” He was not talking to me, nor was he, really, talking to himself. It was like he was talking to a TV camera, as though we were being filmed for B-roll footage for his show — but there was no camera. It was just me and him, standing around that table exhibiting dozens of Apple Watch prototypes that we were unable to touch, with a handful of Apple PR reps hanging around the sides of the room in silence, pecking away on their iPhones, waiting for a notice from one of their colleagues that it was time to escort one of us to our briefing. Oz was called first, thankfully. It gave me a few minutes of silence to gather my thoughts, and study the watches (albeit under glass), without distraction. I sometimes wonder who his briefing was with. (Phil Schiller, perhaps?)

I came away with the impression that Mehmet Oz was, despite his well-deserved medical renown, preternaturally vapid and preening, and, thus, to me, an incongruous figure. Simultaneously a brilliant mind in the field of thoracic surgery, and yet dumb as a rock in everyday human interaction. I spent the first few minutes with him wondering if I should introduce myself. I spent the last few glad I hadn't, because he was so obviously a staggeringly uninteresting and uninterested man.

I would have much preferred spending those 10 minutes chatting with Dr. Nick .

entry.title: Airport — A Typeface Revival
entry.content:
Lukas Schneider:

On 13 November 1961, the Oceanic building at London Airport opened to handle long-haul flight departure. In 1979, German publisher Ravensburger brought out a game designed to help children learn to count. Around Christmas 2023, I stumbled across a copy of that vintage game. The type on the box caught my eye, and that's where this story began.

The letterforms resembled those of Helvetica. As the corners were soft, I initially thought it might be its Rounded version. However, the typeface featured a much larger x-height, the capitals were less wide, and the glyphs also had white bits in some places, yielding a highlight effect. I had never seen this design before. My first suspicion was that it might be a Letraset face, as this would have fitted in well with the release date of the game. Unfortunately, I couldn't find a match in a catalog by this manufacturer of rub-down type, so I contacted Florian Hardwig, who had often helped me with type research in the past. Florian was able to identify the mystery typeface. He found it in a catalog published in 1985 by Layout-Setzerei Stulle, a typesetting service in Stuttgart, Germany. Named Airport Spotlight, it's a derivative of Airport, a typeface that Matthew Carter had designed in the early 1960s for signs at London Airport.

What a gift that Matthew Carter is still with us today. How's this tidbit strike you, regarding the speed at which the world worked just decades ago:

In many regards, the adaptations made to Akzidenz echo the considerations made in the design of Helvetica. In an interview for Computer Arts, Carter comments: “[I]f you look at it today, you'd think was a rip-off of Helvetica. But we'd never seen Helvetica in 1961 in London, although it had been produced in Switzerland near Basle at the Haas foundry in 1957. Even if we had seen it, and wanted to have it typeset in London, we'd have had to get on a plane and fly to Basle and have it typeset there, because the British typesetting trade was so conservative that typefaces like that were simply unobtainable.”

Via Typographica .

★

entry.title: Android Authority: 'Google Is Transforming ChromeOS Into Android'
entry.content:
Mishaal Rahman, reporting for Android Authority:

While both Android and ChromeOS have seen huge success in different markets, they've struggled to compete in one product category where they overlap: tablets. The high-end tablet market is dominated by the Apple iPad, and no matter what Google has tried, it has failed to change that. However, a source tells Android Authority that Google is working on a multi-year project to fully turn ChromeOS into Android, and the end result could be a platform that finally bests the iPad.

可能不会。 Frankly it's kind of weird that Android is a peer to iOS when it comes to phones, but not at all when it comes to tablets, even though iPadOS remains just a big-screen version of iOS. There are zillions of tablets out there that run Android, but they're all crap and everyone knows it. “Flagship Android phones” are a thing; “Flagship Android tablets” are not. And iPads are a huge business for Apple , and the iPad is now solidly established as a piece of our cultural firmament. Everyone knows what an iPad is.

To better compete with the iPad as well as manage engineering resources more effectively, Google wants to unify its operating system efforts. Instead of merging Android and Chrome OS into a new operating system like rumors suggested in the past, however, a source told me that Google is instead working on fully migrating ChromeOS over to Android. While we don't know what this means for the ChromeOS or Chromebook brands, we did hear that Google wants future “Chromebooks” to ship with the Android OS in the future. That's why I believe that Google's rumored new Pixel Laptop will run a new version of desktop Android as opposed to the ChromeOS that you're likely familiar with.

So they're not “merging” the two OSes as rumored, many times, in the past, but they're “fully migrating ChromeOS over to Android”. The only way that really makes a lick of sense is that they're shitcanning ChromeOS and working to make Android not suck on devices other than phones, like laptops and tablets. Good luck with that, given that even Apple has struggled to make iOS/iPadOS a good laptop OS. OS platforms are just hard — hard to design, hard to engineer, hard to evolve. And Apple, for one, seems more committed than ever to the idea that MacOS and iPadOS remain very different platforms.

And, somehow, there's no mention of Fuchsia in Rahman's piece. Fuchsia is supposedly Google's OS of the future, but which more and more is smelling like Google's Copland or Pink — a sprawling “next-gen” OS project that collapses under the weight of its own ambition and lack of practical focus, spinning its wheels for years “in development” whilst the world moves on.

entry.title: DOJ Will Ask Judge to Force Google to Sell Chrome and De-Google Android
entry.content:
Leah Nylen and Josh Sisco, reporting for Bloomberg:

Top Justice Department antitrust officials have decided to ask a judge to force Alphabet Inc.'s Google to sell off its Chrome browser in what would be a historic crackdown on one of the biggest tech companies in the world. [...]

The antitrust officials pulled back from a more severe option that would have forced Google to sell off Android, the people said. [...] The antitrust enforcers are set to propose that Google uncouple its Android smartphone operating system from its other products, including search and its Google Play mobile app store, which are now sold as a bundle, the people said. They are also prepared to seek a requirement that Google share more information with advertisers and give them more control over where their ads appear.

It's hard to say from Bloomberg's second-hand reporting — from people familiar with the matter — what exactly the DOJ is specifically going to ask for. But based on this report, I have to say, neither of these proposals makes much sense.

With Chrome, effectively what the DOJ is saying is that Google, as the monopoly search engine, should be disallowed from making its own web browser (which itself holds a monopoly share on web browsing — which share would be overwhelming if not for Safari). But Chrome, in and of itself, isn't very valuable to anyone other than Google itself. The value Chrome holds to Google is inextricably tied to Chrome's default integration with Google search and other Google web apps.

If Google were forced to sell Chrome, who'd make the default web browser for Android? Android can't ship without a default browser. And the DOJ wants Google to “uncouple” Android from the Google Play store? Allowing Google to keep Android but not make its own web browser or app store is just nonsense. It might make some measure of sense to declare that Google has to sell the desktop version of Chrome — the apps for Windows and Mac — but then what happens to ChromeOS, which is not a monopoly, but is a significant competitor to Windows, MacOS, and iPadOS?

Chrome is not a standalone business. Android is not a standalone business. They're both just appendages of Google that serve only as distribution channels for the advertising Google shows in search results, and the money it makes from advertising and game commissions in the Play Store. It's like saying I have to sell my left foot. It's very valuable to me, but of no value to anyone on its own. (Well, other than spite .)

See Also: Techmeme's roundup .

entry.title: Netflix Claims 60 Million Households Streamed Mike Tyson vs. Jake Paul Fight Friday Night, Straining Quality to Breaking Point for Many
entry.content:
Dominic Patten, reporting for Deadline Friday night:

Netflix's much hyped and much delayed live fight tonight between Mike Tyson and Jake Paul is taking some hits even before the former heavyweight champion and the YouTuber turned boxer have climbed in the ring.

From nearly the start of the undercard bouts from AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, the streamer has been freezing, losing sound and proving slow to reload. While not totally crashing as Netflix did when Luke Cage launched on the streamer in October 2016, the audio on the feed cut out over and over and the quality of the image was reduced to smeared pixels repeatedly.

We watched the whole fight card, and the stream started flaking out early. We had a couple minutes-long segments with what looked like 320p quality, and at other points, the audio completely dropped out for minutes-long stretches, as though the TV were muted. Some people in some places didn't see any glitches, but it seems like most viewers experienced some.

I thought this boded poorly for Netflix's upcoming Christmas Day NFL games (and gave them some shit about it on social media ) but I vastly underestimated just how many people would watch the Tyson-Paul fight. I was thinking the Christmas NFL games would have more viewers than the fight, but it's the other way around. Thanksgiving and Christmas NFL games get about 30 million viewers , but Netflix announced they had 60 million “households” for the fight, peaking at 65 million (and with 50 million watching the great women's title fight that preceded the main event).

That said, the streaming glitches I saw Friday night began early in the evening, during the first fight on the card, a few hours before the main event. It didn't feel to me to like Netflix's live event streaming architecture could handle 30 million viewers, either.

It's easy to forget just how amazing it is that traditional cable TV can deliver a live event to as many people as possible simultaneously. For context, the Super Bowl gets about 100–120 million viewers . Streaming is altogether different. Netflix didn't fall down on this big fight night, but they stumbled.

entry.summary: Apple's S suffix for certain iPhone models — 3GS, 4S, 5S, 6S, XS — has always been problematic in this regard.
entry.content:
Here's the Apple support page listing the devices compatible with iOS 18 . They're listed in chronological order, oldest to newest, and the list begins with the iPhone XR and iPhone XS from 2018. But on this support page, Apple styles the “R” and “S” suffixes as small caps.截屏：

Earlier today I linked to this Apple Newsroom post , regarding the new “Share Location” feature in Find My in iOS 18.2 beta 3. The Apple Newsroom post contains this sentence on iOS 18 compatibility:

Share Item Location is available now in most regions worldwide as part of the public beta of iOS 18.2, which will soon be available to all users as a free software update for iPhone Xs and later.

Is that the iPhone XS, styled with a lowercase s ? Or are they referring to 2017's iPhone X, and pluralizing it with the lowercase s ? By nature of my work, I know that Apple's internal style is never to pluralize a product name like “iPhone X” by adding an s ; they would write something like “iPhone X models” or “iPhone X devices”. But to the casual reader, it's ambiguous. I wound up double-checking on Apple's aforelinked support page for iOS 18 device compatibility, just to be sure. And even there it's only clear because a small caps R has a distinctive uppercase letterform.

Apple's S suffix for certain iPhone models — 3GS, 4S, 5S, 6S, XS — has always been problematic in this regard. It's a particular problem for publications with an all-caps headline style, such as posts here on Daring Fireball. This post from July 2008 , shortly after the iPhone 3G came out, is headlined “iPhone 3Gs in Short Supply”, but when you see it styled on DF itself, it looks like “IPHONE 3GS IN SHORT SUPPLY”. At the time I wrote that, it wasn't confusing at all — the iPhone 3G had only started shipping a few weeks prior, so the iPhone 3GS didn't even exist yet (and with the 3G being the second-ever iPhone model, there wasn't yet any history of Apple applying an S suffix to a model name). If I had it to do all over again, I'd have used an apostrophe (“iPhone 3G's in Short Supply”) or just omitted pluralizing it in the first place (“iPhone 3G in Short Supply”). 1

But the letter S has a second ambiguity problem, in addition to pluralization: its upper and lowercase letterforms are distinguished only by size, not shape, in most roman fonts. That means if you try to distinguish it via the use of small caps, it's to no avail, because a small caps uppercase S looks nearly (if not completely) identical to a lowercase s . And in fact, that's exactly how Apple tends to style the S and R in “iPhone XS” and “iPhone XR”, as evidenced by the screenshot above showing the device compatibility list for iOS 18.

Viewing the HTML source on Apple Newsroom shows that that's how they've styled “XS” in today's post:

 iPhone X<span class="all-small-caps">;s</span>; and later

The all-small-caps class is a simple one-rule style defined in the Apple Newsroom CSS : 2

 .all-small-caps { font-variant-caps:all-small-caps }

Here's where I think Apple could do better. In their HTML markup, they should use an uppercase S inside the span tag delineating the small caps. They should do this:

 <span class="all-small-caps">;S</span>;

instead of this:

 <span class="all-small-caps">;s</span>;

Both of those will render the s in small caps in the browser. But when a user copies and pastes the text from the rendered output in their browser, they'll get the S or s in the same case it is in the HTML, because small-caps styling doesn't carry across copy-and-pasting 。 Whether the original HTML markup uses an uppercase S or lowercase s inside the all-small-caps span, the rendered output users see in their web browser will be a small caps S . But what the user gets when copying and pasting will fall back to the actual case of the S in the HTML code.

Ideally, Apple wants us to see that S in small caps. But it's inevitably going to fall back to simple upper or lowercase after copying and pasting, and in that situation (yes, I was tempted mightily to write case there), it's clearly better to fall back on uppercase, giving copy-and-pasters the unambiguous “iPhone XS”.

Anyway, I'm glad Apple has seemingly abandoned these S-suffixed iPhone names. Next year when the XS and XR age out of support for iOS 19, we might be done writing about them in the present tense.

  1. It's a mistake, and a suggestion of low literacy, to erroneously use the apostrophe-s sequence to pluralize words or names where the proper way to spell the plural is to just add s . Eg, Apple employees are said to bleed six colors , not bleed six color’s . You surely know this. For chrissake you're reading a footnote in a persnickety post regarding best practices in HTML markup for disambiguating product names in uncommon edge cases. But it's not true that one should never form plurals using apostrophes. Per The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage : “Use apostrophes for plurals formed from single letters: He received A's and B's on his report card. Mind your p's and q's. ” My own style guide goes further, and endorses apostrophes for plurals of initialisms in headlines (because of DF's all-caps headline style for short posts), to make clear that in a headline such as, say, “Truckers Are Still Buying CB's”, that they're buying two-way radios, not the television network. ↩︎

  2. I, for one, do not care for Apple's CSS coding style that omits the optional trailing semicolon from the last rule in a block. Makes me just a tad itchy when I see that. 3 ↩︎︎

  3. While I'm straying way out in the coding-style weeds here, let me also observe that I feel old and grumpy about the fact that Apple's HTML markup on Newsroom posts wraps body text paragraphs in <div class="pagebody-copy">; tags, rather than simple semantic <p>; tags. ↩︎︎

;
entry.title: ★ Disambiguating iPhone Model Names That Have the 'S' Suffix

entry.content:
My mom died at the end of June this year.

I know, and I'm sorry — that's a hell of a way to open a piece ostensibly about a depressing, worrisome, frightening election result. But here's the thing I want to emphasize right up front: my mom's death was OK.确实如此。 She was 78, which isn't that old, but her health had not been great. She was hospitalized for several days in May, just a month prior, after she had collapsed at home, too weak to stand, and for days it wasn't clear what was wrong. Then some more test results came back and we had the answer. She had ovarian cancer, bad. It had already metastasized. The prognosis was grim: months to live, at best. And those months, toward the end, would inexorably grow ever more painful and profoundly sad.

Her mental acuity had begun to slip in recent years, too. Not a lot, but if you knew her you'd notice. But she faced this prognosis with remarkable dignity, courage, and clarity. She knew the score. It was what it was, and she'd make the best of the time she had left. She was tired but still felt pretty good most days. There were flashes of her younger self, the Mom I remember growing up with. It was wonderful to see those flashes. The bad times were coming, but they laid ahead. On the last Monday night in June she and my dad went out to eat at their favorite restaurant. They had a good meal and a good time.这是美好的一天。 Tuesday morning she played Wordle and reported her score to our family group chat. Then around noon, she just fell over, dead. My dad found her unresponsive, called 911, and they arrived in minutes, but she was gone.没有痛苦。 The whole dreadful grind of battling cancer never came. It's such a cliché but clichés are often true: given what she faced, it was a blessing she died how and when she did. She never wanted to suffer and she didn't. I loved her and I miss her.

Like I said, it was all OK, in the end — the way and how and when my mom died.

But my dad. My dad is 86, in exceptional good health, and he remains sharp. Until recently he not only played golf but walked the course, carrying his own clubs. He stopped playing golf last year, because — and I realized this only after my mom was hospitalized in May — he'd more and more been shouldering all of the responsibilities of daily life for the both of them. Even just nine holes of golf takes a few hours, and he didn't want to leave her alone for that long a stretch of time, so he stopped playing. He still walks a mile or more a day, weather permitting. They were married 52 years and spent only a handful of nights apart in that entire span. They were in some ways an opposites-attract couple, but they were inseparable. They were good together. After accepting her cancer diagnosis, my mom was ready, I think, even for something as sudden as what happened to her at the end. My dad was not.

But he's an optimist at heart. You'd like him. I, of course, don't know who you are, dear reader, but I know you'd like my dad, Bob Gruber, because everyone likes Bob Gruber. He can tell a good joke and he loves to tell them. There's a quote attributed to Abraham Lincoln, that I was reminded of, just the other day, from of all things a garbage can : “I don't like that man. I must get to know him better.” I don't share Lincoln's there's-something-to-like-about-everyone optimism about our fellow men, but my dad does.

He's been doing good, I think, these months since her passing. I talk to him almost every day. He's naturally outgoing and still goes out. He's got friends — which fact alone can be rare for an 86-year-old — and he sees them regularly. He attends mass frequently and takes tremendous solace in his faith. He misses my mom, his wife, desperately, but he puts on a good face. He gets sad and he admits he gets sad. But the very last thing he wants is for anyone, especially me or my sister, to worry about or even feel sorry for him.我就是这样的。我得到它。 You often hear about old men who just shut down and fade away, rather quickly, after their wives die. My dad's not shutting down.

I thought of my dad this week when I watched Harrison Ford's gravelly endorsement of Kamala Harris , which he began thus: “Look, I've been voting for 64 years. Never really wanted to talk about it very much.” My dad's politics are like that. His religion is too. Strong beliefs that he doesn't feel the need to broadcast or proselytize — and deep suspicion, bordering on contempt, regarding those who do. My dad is old and white and lives in a suburb in a red Pennsylvania county, but he is a lifelong Democrat. He can't abide Fox News and never understood his age-group peers who succumbed to Rush Limbaugh's daily siren call. His entire life he's seen the Democrats as the party of and for the people. The party for working men and women. The party of equality and justice and minding your own goddamn business what people do in their private lives. He votes every election, even the odd years, when the only office on the ballot might be the borough tax collector or members of the school board. He rightly sees voting as a citizen's civic duty. My dad is the most honest and trustworthy person I've ever known, or even imagined. If they ever somehow met, my dad and Joe Biden would become fast friends. They share a worldview, and grew up at the same time, in similar places, from similar means. They even both love trains. (My dad, though, thought Biden was too old to run again. “I know that walk,” he told me early this year, regarding Biden's stiffening gait. He thought it was good, and noble, when Biden dropped out.) He despises Donald Trump and sees right through him.

So, when my dad called me Tuesday morning, I thought it would be the election on his mind. It was all that was on my mind, that's for sure. He had, in fact, just come back from voting, but it was something else. His voice was chipper, upbeat, but I could tell it wasn't a good story.我太了解他了。

Turns out, he had gone out to eat, by himself, Monday evening. In fact, at the very same restaurant where he and my mom ate their last meal together. He ate, drove home, and once home went to wash his hands before going to bed. That's when he noticed his wedding band was missing from his finger.

It was lost.

He looked around to no avail, and went to bed without it. In the morning light, he retraced his steps. He felt certain he had it on while at the restaurant — not because he took any note of it while dining, but because he knows he'd have noticed its absence. If you wear a ring every day on the same finger, you know how true that is. He almost never took that ring off.

At some point when I was a little kid, my dad told me he had never once removed his ring since my mom put it on his finger at their wedding, the year before I was born. My mom, I knew, took hers on and off all the time. In fact she often wore other rings in place of her actual wedding band, because she found them more comfortable, and she placed little sentimental value on the ring from her actual ceremony. I asked my dad that day about his, and he told me he simply had never taken it off. I found that to be amazing. From my childhood perspective, he'd worn that ring nonstop for a lifetime . He broke that streak eventually, for some small reason, and it wasn't a big deal to him, the never-having-taken-it-off thing. But I knew from that time I asked him about it as a child, that the ring itself was deeply important to him, in a way that my mom didn't feel about hers. Some people imbue meaning and sentimental importance to certain objects. My dad saw his wedding ring like that. It was a sacred token. And now he'd lost it.

Through my youth — his 30s and 40s and early 50s — my dad always looked how I'd describe as “of average build”. Neither thin nor heavy. Strong but not muscled. He looked like the sort of man who in his youth played third base, and batted near the top of the order, which he did. A former athlete who could still hit the living shit out of a golf ball. In his middle age, he gained a bit of a paunch. (It happens, I now know.) But in the last few years he's lost quite a bit of weight. He's downright bony now, in an old man way. His old pants (and nearly all his pants are old — he's 86) need to be cinched with a belt or they'd fall right off him. His fingers too, have gotten bony. So his ring had gotten loose. He'd offhandedly mentioned that fact to me a few months ago even, telling me he needed to be careful whenever his hands might get wet.

After waking Tuesday morning, he searched everywhere he could think it might be.厨房。浴室。 The shower.水槽。 The other sink. He took the couch cushions off. He looked in his car. He went back in the house and searched everywhere all over again. He took a break to vote, came home, and went back out and searched the car again, this time with a flashlight.无济于事。 It's a sick feeling after you've lost something of value, when you start losing count of how many times you've looked for it in the exact same places you've already checked. You can't stop looking, but can't think of new places to search.

He called the restaurant, but they weren't yet open, so he left a message, leaving his name and number in case anyone had found a simple well-worn gold wedding band — and if no one had, well, maybe could they keep an eye out for it. He called me after he left that message. He wasn't forlorn. He laughed even. That's how he is.我就是这样。我们就是这样。 I'm his boy, as he still sometimes reminds me. But I know what that ring meant to him.

And my mom had just died so recently. It has only been a few months. The seasons have only changed once since we buried her.

他妈的。

It was a bad start to a day that I began, like any keen political junkie, with a nervous feeling. I'm not superstitious but a bad omen is a bad omen. You want every little thing to break right on a high-stress big day, and Election Day, for us, had begun with a small heartbreak. I told my wife about my dad's ring and she almost burst into tears. She loves him so much. “He just lost your mom”, she said.

You know how the rest of Election Day went. My wife and I voted. We both like the ceremony of voting in-person on Election Day. It helps that we live in a neighborhood with a vibrant civil infrastructure, with no-wait polling places no more than a block or two away from any residence. We were both feeling good.

但然后呢？ I was reminded, once again, that I never know what to do with myself on Election Day in a presidential election. No information or results can be gleaned until polling places start closing in early states at 7pm ET. What do you do until then? It seemed pointless for me to write anything further about the election, but equally futile to think I could concentrate on anything else. Expounding upon Kottke's treatise on the art of hypertext writing was a good distraction . I got to write about something I care about, and because the inspiration was the NYT editorial board's receipts-packed 110-word admonition to end the Trump era , my effort felt at least tangentially related to the election that was then (and alas, remains now) front of mind for me. I could focus on that, and I didn't finish it until just before 7:00pm.完美的。

That's Kornacki time . Steve Kornacki's data-driven, map-based analysis has been the heart and soul of MSNBC's presidential election night coverage for all three Trump elections: 2016, 2020, and now 2024. I honestly don't remember how I watched election results before Kornacki. I know I've been watching election night results on TV since at least 1992. As best I can recall, before 2016, I'd flip around between CNN, MSNBC, and the broadcast networks. I basically just “watched the news on TV”, not on any particular channel. But starting in 2016, we just watch Kornacki. We put on MSNBC and we don't flip. The desk chatter amongst commentators and panelists that consumes the time between Kornacki updates is background noise. But what Kornacki does is genius. Maybe the other networks have caught up and do something similar now. I don't know, because I no longer flip.

The way it works is that every news operation has a “decision desk”. The decision desk staffers are off-screen analysts, not on-air talent. They call state-by-state results only with absolute certainty. That absolute certainty can and usually does come before every single vote in a state has been counted, but comes after the likely winner is ascertainable beyond a reasonable doubt. The decision desks make their calls not when the writing appears on the wall, but when the paint has started to dry.

They weren't always so fastidious, because nerve-rackingly close results in American presidential elections used to be the exception, not the norm. But after the contentious and almost impossibly close election of 2000, when, on election night, multiple networks — including Fox News — had projected Al Gore the winner early in the evening , based on exit polls rather than tabulated votes, every such major decision desk has become quite rigorous about this, regardless of the political bent of the network or publication. Rigorous to the point of almost entirely avoiding controversy. We can see that even now, on Friday 8 November, as I write this. At the moment, none of the major decision desks have yet called Arizona or Nevada, despite it being a near-certainty Trump won both. The only exception I can recall was four years ago, when Fox News called Arizona for Biden at midnight and the AP followed a few hours later . Biden did in fact win Arizona, but when Fox and the AP called it for him, with 80 percent of the state's ballots counted, Biden was ahead by a seemingly comfortable 9 percent. By the time all ballots had been counted, days later, the margin had closed to a whisker-thin 0.3 percent. They were correct, but by their own standards of rigor were mistaken to call it when they did. It's an interesting sign of how independent the Fox News decision desk is, though, that when they got reckless, it was in Biden's direction.

What Steve Kornacki does at MSNBC is make de facto calls without making actual calls. Or better put, he presents real-time data and context that allows you, the attentive viewer, to start making calls long before the decision desks reach their standards of absolute certainty. “You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows” goes the Bob Dylan line. Steve Kornacki isn't the weatherman. He's our finger in the air.

What he does is find telltale counties in important states. A suburb of Atlanta. A suburb of Charlotte. A suburb of Philadelphia. With, say, half the vote counted, he might show that Harris is winning 75-25 in that county. That's a solidly blue county. A 50-point margin is, you know, good. But then comes the context. That same county, let's say, went 80-20 for Biden in 2020, and went 75-25 for Hillary Clinton in 2016. Now that 75-25 margin for Harris doesn't look good. It looks like 2016, not like 2020. Or go the other way. Kornacki finds small rural counties of note. Some red county Trump was certain to win, but which he was winning this year by margins that looked like those in 2016, not 2020.

It's quite remarkable, Kornacki's gift. He presents the story, the explanation of how the election results are going, without ever saying what exactly it is he is explaining. He shows you just the right trees to give you a sense of the entire forest. He never says “It looks like Trump is going to win North Carolina.” He simply presents facts, cold hard facts, that, if you consider them, explain why it looks like Trump is going to win North Carolina. They are conclusions left for you, the viewer, to draw. It's incredibly disciplined. But he never ever gets ahead of the actual NBC News decision desk. He doesn't have to. The way he does what he does, he can't be wrong. If Kornacki paints a picture of live data and historical results that indicate that Trump is heading toward a win in, say, Georgia, hours before any official decision desk call is made, that's because the data available up to that point just factually shows that Trump is on a path to win Georgia. And if something were to happen with the remaining votes that change that path, he'll simply present that new data as it comes in, later in the evening.

Closely watching Kornacki didn't mean I knew Trump was going to win early in the evening. But it meant I knew it sure looked like he was going to. I was concerned when Florida's results came in, shortly after their polls closed at 8pm. (Say what you will about their debacle in 2000, but in the aftermath, Florida got its shit together and now tabulates the entirety of their statewide vote with remarkable alacrity and promptness.) I of course had no expectation that Harris might win Florida, but she lost by 13 points . Trump only won Florida four years ago by 3 points . That swing alone was an ominous early sign of the nationwide trend. That's when the pit formed in my stomach.呃哦。

I don't flip channels but I do of course watch with my phone in hand. The New York Times's infamous “needle” lurched sickeningly rightward early. I stopped looking at it, but not because I thought it was mistaken. Because I knew it was probably correct. By 10pm or so, it seemed obvious that Harris's only plausible path to victory was for three states — Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin — to buck the nationwide trend of red counties getting redder, and blue counties getting slightly less blue. There was reason for hope, but not much. It was like “ Tom Brady could lead the Patriots to a comeback in the Super Bowl even though they're down 28-3 in the third quarter ” hope. That happened , but that's not how 28-3 football games tend to go. That's not how elections tend to go. And it's not how this one went. At 11:20pm, my friend Taegan Goddard wrote this lede in a post at Political Wire : “Donald Trump is now very likely to win re-election. He has the edge in Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin — all states Kamala Harris needs to win.” I wasn't yet at the point where I'd have put that into such stark words, but I knew they were true.就这样。

I watched MSNBC for another hour, but only with resignation, not hope. I watched a Harris spokesman take the podium at her stage at Howard University and tell the nation she wouldn't be speaking until Wednesday — just like 2016. I posted one brief item here , commenting only, “Strong déjà vu as acceptance sets in. ”

I woke early on Wednesday, at least by my night owl standards. A gut punch is not a sleep aid. My dad called, just after 9:30am. He seldom calls that early, knowing my sleep habits. I hadn't stopped feeling heartsick about his ring. His voice though, was excited. He'd gone to mass that morning, driven home, and parked in front of his house. (Still hard for me not to call it their house.) Same exact spot where he'd parked the night he lost the ring. It's a one-way street, and in front of his house, cars park on the left. He opened the car door and thought to look down, just in case.在那里。他的戒指。 In the street, between his car and the curb, nestled amidst some dry leaves. It must have fallen off his finger as he was opening the car door that night, and the leaves perhaps deadened any clink it might have made hitting the ground. If that parking spot hadn't been open again, he wouldn't have found it then and there. If it had rained, it would have washed away.

He said, “John, when I picked that ring up, I kissed it. 52 years I've had this ring on my finger. I thanked St. Anthony, and I thanked your mother. I think she found it for me.”

Given the circumstances when I went to bed Tuesday night, it was no surprise I was welling up with tears come the morning. But I'd never have expected they'd be tears of joy, with a sense of hope — however diminished — and abiding love in my heart.
